posts.post_content:
1. [Ertai, the Corrupted](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ertai, the Corrupted)  
2. [Lullmage Mentor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lullmage Mentor)  
3. [Sea Scryer](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sea Scryer)  
4. [Carnival of Souls](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Carnival of Souls)  
5. [Intruder Alarm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Intruder Alarm)  
6. [Soul Warden](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Soul Warden)  
  
  
Other recommendations: A sacrificial creature to start the process.  
  
The process:   
A. The opponent casts a spell, you pay ![Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=U&type=symbol) and sacrifice a creature to counter it.  
B. Once this resolves, you just countered an opponents spell, so [Lullmage Mentor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lullmage Mentor) activates giving you a creature token.  
C. Since you just got a creature, [Carnival of Souls](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Carnival of Souls) takes 1 life, and gives you one black mana.  
D. Again, since you just got a creature, [Soul Warden](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Soul Warden) gives you back the life you lost in Step C.  
E. Yet again, since you just got a creature, [Intruder Alarm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Intruder Alarm) untaps everything, including Ertai and the Sea Scryer  
F. You have ![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol) in your mana pool. If another spell is cast, tap the ... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

The process:
A. The opponent casts a spell, you pay and sacrifice a creature to counter it.
B. Once this resolves, you just countered an opponents spell, so Lullmage Mentor activates giving you a creature token.
C. Since you just got a creature, Carnival of Souls takes 1 life, and gives you one black mana.
D. Again, since you just got a creature, Soul Warden gives you back the life you lost in Step C.
E. Yet again, since you just got a creature, Intruder Alarm untaps everything, including Ertai and the Sea Scryer
F. You have in your mana pool. If another spell is cast, tap the ... (see all)

Posted By: adrian.malacoda (1/23/2012 4:30:12 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Best used with enchantments that return to hand. Rancor is the most memorable but \*not\* the best for this guy. Mostly since its not in his colors. Better to use Brilliant Halo, Cessation, Despondency, Diabolic Servitude (For the creature, not the enchantment), Fool's Demise, Fallen Ideal, Launch, Sleeper's Guile, Slow Motion, and Spirit Loop.  
  
See: 10 auras in his colors with the "Rancor" effect without having to splash green for Rancor. Several of them are quite playable too. Only reason people say "Auras stink" is because if the creature dies your out one whole card. If it was a negative-effect aura, you would have been better off controlling or killing it rather than weakening. But the auras I listed above are different. Since they come back they aren't disadvantageous (or at least AS disadvantageous).  
  
All-in-all, his major advantage over Ertai 1.0 is the fact he is three colors, giving you more options in EDH. The {U} cost is much nicer than the {2}{U}{U} cost as well, le... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Posted By: Etregan (11/17/2009 1:18:33 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: I have seen a plethora of amazingly good cards before, and Ertai by far is probably one of the best. His ability is simply astounding, granted that you have several tokens in play or creatures (or enchantments) that you don't need, allowing you to control exactly what your opponent plays through-out the rest of the game. This definitely fits right in the with the esper colors; restrictive abilities that neutralize the opponent and allow you to control them. The only downside to Ertai is that if your not playing tokens or lost of enchantments then it can become quite difficult to use him effectively. Also Ertai's ability can only be played once per turn, but with cards like [Thousand-Year Elixir](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Thousand-Year Elixir) and other untapping abilities this minor weakness can easily be overlooked.
posts.html:

Posted By: majinara (6/30/2012 6:36:35 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: Favorite card in my ertai deck: [fool's demise](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=fool's demise). You can sac it to counter a spell and it goes back to your hand. You can play it on your own creatures to bring them back after being sacrificed, which is awesome with cards like [rune-scarred demon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=rune-scarred demon) or [grave titan](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=grave titan). Or since you've got all of those wonderful black and white removal options, you can turn it into a reusable enchantment-free mind control.
posts.html:
Favorite card in my ertai deck: fool's demise. You can sac it to counter a spell and it goes back to your hand. You can play it on your own creatures to bring them back after being sacrificed, which is awesome with cards like rune-scarred demon or grave titan. Or since you've got all of those wonderful black and white removal options, you can turn it into a reusable enchantment-free mind control.

posts.post_content:
He has extra forearms just like certain [Eldumbzi](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=193634)!  
  
Ertai is a neat character, and makes for a nice EDH/ Commander general, but his ability just isn't up to snuff. He can't use it immediately unless you give him [haste](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=247337), and even then you need a enchantment/ creature to fuel it. Basically, it's a slightly more versatile [Abjure](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Abjure) on a stick. For 5 in 3 colors? Not impressed.
posts.html:
He has extra forearms just like certain Eldumbzi!

Ertai is a neat character, and makes for a nice EDH/ Commander general, but his ability just isn't up to snuff. He can't use it immediately unless you give him haste, and even then you need a enchantment/ creature to fuel it. Basically, it's a slightly more versatile Abjure on a stick. For 5 in 3 colors? Not impressed.
